title: In French, when do I use “le” and “la”? - Quora

response.answer_text: Le and La are definite articles, similar to saying the chair or the dog. I’ve already written on how these words work in Spanish and it’s not much different in French, however, I’ll be adding one bonus word. The definite articles are used before the noun, such as the word the is in English. There’s not too much difficulty, but you may be confused about when to use Le or La, and this is pretty straightforward as well.  Cover photo :>  First, you need to know the grammatical gender of the word in question. This is if the word is feminine or masculine, throughout my years of studying French I’ve learned that if it ends with an E, it’s most probably feminine. Dictionaries are always your best friend here, so use one if you’re confused. Now that you have the gender, you just have to pick one. Le is used for masculine words while La is used for feminine words.  Oh but there’s a catch in French, that bonus word I mentioned at the beginning. If the word starts with a vowel (you should already know those), you won’t use either, and just go with l’ instead.  If you’re using the plural, however, drop l’ and go with les. Les can be used for both feminine and masculine, as well as for words starting with a vowel.  Thanks for differentiating my answer, Zinedine

“Le” is used as a masculine noun or concept( even emotions) examples are: The boy-Le garçon , courage- Le courage “ la “ is for the feminine noun or concepts ex: The apple- la pomme , sadness- la tristesse For a better understanding when to use “la” and “le”, you can use “un”, “une” or for plural nouns “des” Yet, in English “un” or “une” is translated as “a” Ex: Une pomme - la pomme -the apple Un garçon- le garçon- the boy
